captions.text: It's hard to imagine an animal more charming than the panda.
Blessed with both looks and personality,
these bears are China's most popular ambassadors.
The only thing more irresistible than an adult panda
a panda cub looks like a kid in a bear suit
or a plush toy come to life.
Pandas are highly endangered and they are the rarest bears in the world.
So every panda birth is a reason to celebrate.
has the largest population of captive pandas anywhere in the world.
They have bred more pandas here than just about anywhere else.
But in the future they also hope to release some pandas back into the wild.

comments.text:

comments.author: rose 白

comments.text:
+Panzer Blitz WTF? LOL! You are so unbelievably stupid. China is a 5,000+ 
years old civilization state. It has 56 ethnicities and a very broad 
spectrum of cultures. For example, the cultural values of Northern China 
differ so drastically from that of Southern China and we can see that just 
in the food they eat. Each region has its own unique Chinese dialect and 
traditional celebrations. How foolish it is to say China has no culture!

Culture has nothing to do with being selfish. After all, the human race is 
a selfish specie. We take from nature the resources we need and slaughter 
animals for food. Everything is about what more can we have and look at 
what we've done: global warming, endangered animal species, wars, growing 
gap between the rich and poor. If you think about it, capitalism is a 
system based on selfishness.

We have cultures too. Yet we had horrible practices like colonialism and 
slavery in the past as well. Having a culture doesn't mean having 
impeccable morals.

Don't go around saying fabricated things on a whim. It reveals the lack of 
credibility in everything you post and your willingness to distort and make 
up things to prove nothing but a lie.
comments.author: Tony Anderson

comments.author: rose 白

comments.text:
+William Zhao All I saw was some shit about China saying they'll do this 
and promising to do that. Meanwhile, right now, today, China is one of, if 
not *the biggest* single contributor to the consumption of fossil fuels. 
Not only that, but it's getting *worse* and will continue to do so, despite 
what efforts your government says it's making; all you need to do is look 
at supply and demand and you'll see the world relies on China's 
manufacturing capabilities and you'll quickly realise China's not getting 
environmentally friendly any time soon. And I'm sorry, but trying to debate 
whether or not China censors its media is just laughable. It's like that 
general guy that would openly lie to the Iraqi media outlets, telling them 
America is being beaten, meanwhile coalition tanks are rolling through 
Baghdad.
comments.author: Terry Sawyer

comments.text:
+Panzer Blitz I already argued against your points in an earlier post, if 
you have nothing new to contribute, stop talking to me. At least, don't 
repeat the same stuff. It's absolutely boring and a complete waste of time 
to read the same stuff again.
comments.author: William Zhao

comments.text:
+Terry Sawyer lmfao. You need to update your knowledge of what's current 
news regarding China. The Chinese government has already implemented 
numerous measures and policies to ensure that coal consumption will be 
banned in major cities by 2017. By 2030, China won't be using coal for 
energy anymore. For starters, hundreds of poorly managed factories that 
contributed to pollution were already closed down. Plus, China made deals 
with Russia for natural gas and is atm having deals made with Australia as 
well. And on the issue of China denying pollution, animal smuggling, animal 
poaching and human rights problem, China does indeed censor those 
information. So what? It's not like the Chinese public doesn't know. You 
need to actually travel there and ask around. The Chinese people know about 
the pollution, the censorship, animal smuggling and poaching. It's hardly 
news. Plus, pollution is a product of capitalism. It's not like China 
invented it. The west created the industrial age and simply relocated it to 
Asia. India has pollution, Vietnam has it too, Philippines as well. For the 
animal poaching, Europeans and Americans travel to Africa and kill animals 
all the time. Right ... you guys don't call that poaching, you call it 
sportive hunting, aka entertainment. Like that's any better. Human rights? 
Under the patriot act, that's something equivalent as farce. Censorship? 
Someone forgot about Edward Snowden? When democratic states brand 
journalists who expose unprecedented scales of human rights violations 
exercised by the government for the good of mankind, what did those who 
have always promoted freedom of speech actually do? They branded Edward 
Snowden and Glenn Greenwald as criminals and force them to become 
fugitives. Hell, Britain even arrested Glenn Greenwald's partner and 
demanded the Guardian newspaper to dispose of materials related to that 
case. For a democratic society, that's ironic. Human rights and freedom of 
speech don't exist. Stop being naive. We all live with the limited amount 
of freedom our governments allow us to have. Some governments have the most 
advanced technologies to spy on its citizens without them knowing, so 
people innocently believe they have freedom. That's not a privilege. That's 
called ignorance is a bliss.
comments.author: William Zhao

comments.text:
China doesn't give a fuck about human rights, let alone animal rights. Yes, 
the pollution in China is *partly* due to China's colossal population 
crisis, in that there are *over 62 million* vehicles on China's roads - up 
from around 5 million in 1990. Having countless coal-burning (AKA fossil 
fuels - and can anyone else spell 'greenhouse gasses'?) factories really 
isn't helping either. China is just one titanic factory, and it's effect on 
the environment is as you'd expect from a factory with 1.4 billion workers 
in it.

+William Zhao The first article you linked referred to a reformed law in 
which there will be fines that *may* deter people from polluting, but the 
problem is that a large majority of China's income is from the factories 
that cause half the pollution in the first place. On the surface, China's 
government is just like any other; they're against all the bad stuff and 
only want the good things to happen, but as soon as someone actually 
investigates the pollution, animal smuggling, animal poaching or human 
rights problems, their work is immediately censored from China's media and 
the government does what it can to deny the /accusations/.

I won't deny that there are nice Chinese people, but, likewise, nobody in 
their right mind can deny the terrible effects the country has on our 
planet.
comments.author: Terry Sawyer

comments.text:
+William Zhao China's borders are controlled by a massive police force, so 
they do have a way to stop illegal smuggling more than most other 
countries. China and Vietnam are the villains which are exterminating 
African wildlife. Asian countries will torture and eat anything that walks 
or crawls, they want to "farm" and inflict cruelty on pets and wildlife, 
they rape the oceans and have practically destroyed all Asian wildlife 
species for greed. When Philippines caught China's ships illegally poaching 
turtles, Chinese authorities objected to the Philippines detaining those 
ships and holding their crew for charges. What does that tell you about 
corruption in China?
comments.author: Panzer Blitz

comments.text:
+Panzer Blitz You make it sound as if China disregards pollution as 
unimportant and tolerates illegal poaching practices. That's certainly not 
the case. First of all, the Chinese government takes pollution very 
seriously. 
http://www.earthisland.org/journal/index.php/elist/eListRead/is_china_turning_the_corner_on_environmental_protection/
They are making drastic economic and social reforms in the manufacturing 
sector, for example by cutting down coal consumptions, to fix the pollution 
problem. Also, why is it China's responsibility to oversee illegal 
activities happening overseas? If poachers smuggle African wildlife, it is 
entirely up to the African governments to enforce the laws and prevent 
those crimes from happening. The Chinese government has no reason nor the 
authority to interfere with wildlife affairs happening on African soil. 
It's quite absurd to think that China should. Most importantly, you do have 
to realize that the Chinese government does not condone poaching and 
killing wildlife, right? After all, they are illegal in China; poachers 
will be arrested, fined and sent to prison if caught. If you want to refer 
some governments that actually tolerate such activities, then perhaps you 
should visit: 
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/21/japanese-fishermen-begin-annual-slaughter-of-hundreds-of-dolphins
 
http://www.harpseals.org/about_the_hunt/index.php
http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/nov/19/australian-government-to-scrutinise-new-japanese-whaling-plan
comments.author: William Zhao

comments.text: Its ur opinion.

comments.text:
+Zeppelin Bear Your ancestors lived under those exact same pollutions 
during the industrial revolution. But of course, your ignorance blinds you 
from the obvious fact. Their sacrifice realized the wealthy state you 
currently live in. Nonetheless, you would probably categorize them shit as 
well, for they made the contributions while living under considerably 
polluted environments. Furthermore, your comparison of London, Paris, Los 
Angeles, Athens with Chinese cities only indicates a ludicrous skill in 
math and logical reasoning. Ever think of the population ratios between the 
two groups? Like what you have stated, all those European and American 
cities still exhibit high smog levels. It would simply be irrational to 
assume that China, at the peak of its economic change and industrial 
transformation, will not undergo a similar stage of great pollution.
comments.author: William Zhao

comments.author: Midnite Reveries

comments.text:
Actually, pandas (red and giant) are not bears. They are not related to 
bears at all. There are many physical differences between pandas and bears 
to prove it. Pandas are part of the bandit family making them more closely 
related to raccoons which makes sense when you look at red pandas.

comments.author: Golden Soul

comments.text:
+Grossly Incandescent Panda Bear, or "Giant Panda": Kingdom: Animalia
Phylum: Chordata
Class: Mammalia
Order: Carnivora
Family: Ursidae
Genus: Ailuropoda
Species: A. melanoleuca
------- American Black Bear: Kingdom: Animalia
Phylum: Chordata
Class: Mammalia
Order: Carnivora
Family: Ursidae
Genus: Ursus
Species: U. americanus ---- What you need to look for there is the Family. 
They both belong to Ursidae, and thus they're both bears. See how they are 
identical, until Genus? This is obvious, because it seperates what GENE's 
the animal has, which determines what TYPE of the broad classification the 
animal is. In this case, it's a bear. The Panda is very much a bear. It's 
as much a bear as the American Black Bear, Asiatic Black Bear, Asian Sun 
Bear and Grizzly Bear. The main contributor to why you never hear of "man 
attacked by Panda" is because there's just under 1,600 Panda's in the wild, 
and they live in extremely remote parts of forests that human beings very 
rarely enter.

comments.text:
